unnormalised: The Ministry of Education has announced revisions to the Common University Entrance Test (CUET) UG for the academic year 2025-26. As per the notification released on 20/07/2024, the CUET UG will now be conducted in a hybrid mode, combining both online and offline testing options. This decision aims to accommodate students from diverse backgrounds and with varying access to technology, particularly those in rural areas like Bihar and Odisha. The application process is slated to commence on 01/02/2025.
normalised: The Ministry of Education has announced revisions to the Common University Entrance Test (C-U-E-T) U-G for the academic year two thousand twenty five two thousand twenty six. As per the notification released on twentieth july two thousand twenty four, the C-U-E-T U-G will now be conducted in a hybrid mode, combining both online and offline testing options. This decision aims to accommodate students from diverse backgrounds and with varying access to technology, particularly those in rural areas like Bihar and Odisha. The application process is slated to commence on first february two thousand twenty five.

unnormalised: The revised CUET UG format will feature a maximum of 6 subjects that can be chosen by the students. The objective is to ease the burden on students and allow them to focus on their areas of expertise. The test syllabus will remain aligned with the NCERT Class XII curriculum, ensuring fair competition. Detailed information regarding the exam pattern, syllabus, and important dates will be available on the official NTA website (nta.ac.in) from 15/01/2025.
normalised: The revised C-U-E-T U-G format will feature a maximum of six subjects that can be chosen by the students. The objective is to ease the burden on students and allow them to focus on their areas of expertise. The test syllabus will remain aligned with the N-C-E-R-T Class Twelve curriculum, ensuring fair competition. Detailed information regarding the exam pattern, syllabus, and important dates will be available on the official N-T-A website (n-t-a dot a-c dot i-n) from fifteenth january two thousand twenty five.

unnormalised: Furthermore, the Ministry has directed all participating universities, including Delhi University, JNU, and BHU, to revise their admission criteria accordingly. The weightage given to CUET scores will be a minimum of 75%, with the remaining 25% left to the discretion of individual universities, which may include interviews or other assessment methods. This move is intended to maintain academic rigor and provide a holistic evaluation of candidates.
normalised: Furthermore, the Ministry has directed all participating universities, including Delhi University, J-N-U, and B-H-U, to revise their admission criteria accordingly. The weightage given to C-U-E-T scores will be a minimum of seventy five percent, with the remaining twenty five percent left to the discretion of individual universities, which may include interviews or other assessment methods. This move is intended to maintain academic rigor and provide a holistic evaluation of candidates.

unnormalised: Prof. Rajesh Kumar, Chairman of the UGC, stated that "these changes are aimed at making higher education more accessible and equitable for all students across India. We want to ensure that no deserving candidate is left behind due to logistical challenges or socio-economic disparities." He also mentioned that special provisions will be made for students from economically weaker sections (EWS) and those with disabilities (PwD).
